posts.title: Introduction to eBrain
posts.subtitle: Your Gateway to Microcontrollers
posts.description: Welcome, young explorer! Today you'll begin your journey into the world of microcontrollers with the eBrain. This remarkable device transforms your code into real-world action.

posts.title: eBrain Features
posts.subtitle: Designed for Innovators
posts.description: The eBrain is built for inventors and tinkerers. It works seamlessly with Snap!, Python, and Arduino IDE, bridging the digital and physical worlds.

content.name: Interactive Projects
content.info: Build systems that respond to automation.

content.name: Hands-On Learning
content.info: Connect circuits and code for real-world interactions.

content.name: Prototype Quickly
content.info: Test your ideas without a complex setup.

elements.content: It empowers you to create smart, responsive projects that make your ideas come alive.

posts.title: Board Layout
posts.subtitle: Mapping the Microcontroller
posts.description: Understanding your board is key. Explore the layout of the eBrain to know where to connect your sensors and peripherals.

posts.title: Unboxing the Kit
posts.subtitle: What's in the Package
posts.description: Discover the carefully selected components included in your eBrain kit—everything you need to start building.

posts.title: Programming with Snap!
posts.subtitle: Visual, Block-Based Coding
posts.description: Snap! offers an intuitive, visual approach to programming your eBrain. It lets you build complex logic without typing a single line of code.

posts.title: Powering Up
posts.subtitle: Battery Setup
posts.description: Learn how to power your eBrain. Insert 4 AA batteries correctly to supply the board with the necessary voltage.

posts.title: Power Supply Details
posts.subtitle: Voltage Regulation
posts.description: Your eBrain uses 4 AA batteries (totaling 6V) which is regulated down to a stable 3.3V output.

posts.title: Patch Bay Overview
posts.subtitle: Connecting Components
posts.description: The patch bay allows you to quickly interface sensors, LEDs, and other peripherals with your eBrain.

posts.title: RGB LED
posts.subtitle: Vibrant Visuals
posts.description: The eBrain features a high-precision RGB LED capable of producing over 16 million colors through additive mixing.

posts.title: Wiring Overview
posts.subtitle: Using Patch Cables
posts.description: Patch cables connect your eBrain to various components. Their modular design makes wiring flexible and easy.

posts.title: Button Controls
posts.subtitle: Activating Circuits
posts.description: Your eBrain's built-in buttons allow you to complete circuits without additional wiring. They are directly connected to the power source.

items: Connect a male-to-male wire between patch bay ports R and 1.
Press button S1 to complete the circuit.

posts.title: Quick Challenge: External LED
posts.subtitle: Build a Circuit
posts.description: Use the breadboard, patch cables, and buttons to build a circuit controlling an external LED. Test your understanding with this hands-on challenge.

elements.content: LED stands for Light Emitting Diode. What is a diode?

posts.title: Breadboard Basics
posts.subtitle: Simplify Your Prototypes
posts.description: Breadboards let you quickly assemble and modify circuits without soldering, thanks to their conductive clips.

elements.content: Think of a breadboard as a team of helping hands that hold wires together.

posts.title: Using the Breadboard
posts.subtitle: Practical Application
posts.description: Learn how to use the breadboard to create circuits by plugging wires into its conductive columns.

elements.content: The breadboard clips wires together so you don’t have to hold them manually.

posts.title: Inside the Breadboard
posts.subtitle: The Hidden Structure
posts.description: Peek inside the breadboard to see how its metal clips secure your connections and ensure continuity.

elements.content: The clips are arranged in rows and columns to transmit electricity efficiently.

posts.title: Wire Connectivity
posts.subtitle: Experiment with Circuits
posts.description: Test how wire placement affects connectivity on the breadboard. Notice the difference when wires share the same column.

items: Place wires in the same column to complete the circuit and light up an LED.
Place wires in different columns to break the circuit.

posts.title: RGB Color Mixing
posts.subtitle: Experiment with Hues
posts.description: Mix RGB colors on the breadboard by connecting different colored wires to the power source. Observe the new hues that are formed.

items: Connect each colored LED to the 3.3V source.
Experiment with different combinations to see the resulting color.

posts.title: RGB Mixing Results
posts.subtitle: The Final Hues
posts.description: Discover the outcomes of additive color mixing: which combinations yield yellow, magenta, cyan, or white.

elements.content: Red + Green = Yellow, Red + Blue = Magenta, Green + Blue = Cyan, All three = White.
elements.note: Additive color mixing differs from mixing paints.

posts.title: eBrain Buttons
posts.subtitle: Built-In Controls
posts.description: Your eBrain includes 4 buttons that quickly complete circuits, allowing you to control various functions.

elements.content: These buttons are directly connected to the battery, so no extra wiring is needed.

posts.title: Final Review
posts.subtitle: Recap and Summary
posts.description: Congratulations! Let's review the key components and concepts of your eBrain.

elements.content: Great Job! You've mastered the essential parts of your eBrain, laying the foundation for advanced projects.

items: Power bay: Battery connection & voltage regulation.
Patch bay: Connecting sensors and peripherals.
